Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Learning From Nature: Marine Educational Games With Big IDEAS (Innovative Differentiated Educational Assessments in Science)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase II project will develop an easy to use real-time formative assessment tool for educators that will be uniquely aligned to each student and deployed via a virtual reality learning game that uses venomous marine snails as a conduit for exploring scientific issues in nature. The USA is currently ranked 52nd in the world in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) education. This is detrimental intellectually and economically to the future of American society. Recent studies indicate it is not what is taught, but how it is taught that enhances student-learning abilities, particularly as it pertains to STEM. As a result, this project is driven by the research objectives to understand how children learn specific science content and why certain game elements are better suited to convey scientific material. The outcome of this project is a proprietary multi-tiered formative assessment tool that can measure real time student learning of novel STEM content obtained through a virtual reality learning game experience. This project will enable teachers to nimbly tailor future instruction with individualized student learning goals. Commercialization of the products created in this project will transform scientific learning and measurable engagement in educational games for social and economic benefit to meet the NSF?s mission of supporting education initiatives that improve the lives of U.S. Citizens, and generate income for tax revenue and jobs via the employment of software designers, educators and scientists.

The proprietary technology developed in this SBIR Phase II will be a first-of-its-kind assessment dashboard that will link virtual reality and web-based learning environments with formative assessment to fuel instruction and deepen learning. This project will build proprietary assessment tools into online and virtual reality games which continuously engage users in the process of scientific inquiry and discovery using novel formative assessments customized to each player. The proprietary assessment dashboard allows teachers and players to measure their progress in real-time and identify opportunities to enhance their STEM learning. Using Unity as the platform, player actions and decisions will be met with tailored formative assessments and ongoing feedback throughout game play. This feedback helps teachers delineate where their students are along their learning progressions and fuels further instruction. The novel approach of this assessment dashboard transforms qualitative and quantitative learning and has the potential to significantly enhance student engagement and commitment to scientific inquiry to support emerging science changemakers. The research objective of the player/teacher dashboard is to align feedback on student learning during game play with dynamic quantitative and qualitative formative assessment that create a seamless demonstration of knowledge acquisition while providing teachers with multiple opportunities to engage learners in deeper and more meaningful levels of inquiry before, during, and after gameplay. The products generated from this project are aligned to the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) and the International Baccalaureate (IB) program to ensure the content is of the highest caliber and distribution is to a large global customer base. The anticipated results from exposing teachers and students to this project will be increased competencies in STEM, which will transform players into lifelong learners and enhance engagement in STEM fields and careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview  

Killer Snails creates imaginative game-based science learning experiences that capture the excitement and challenges of being a scientist. The mission of Killer Snails is to create the next generation of changemakers and to bring science out of the laboratory and into the hands of learners globally.  Team Killer Snails (KS) had three objectives during our NSF-Phase II award: 1) Finalize development of our formative assessment dashboard prototype begun in Phase 1, which is a validated customer desire. 2) Build a dynamic immersive environment using virtual reality (VR) that supports deeper learning and extends student inquiry to provide differentiated assessment as dynamic as the players themselves, a stated need uncovered in our customer interviews.  3) develop a virtual reality assessment dashboard that tracks movement within the game to seamlessly feed into our formative assessment dashboard prototype. These concurrent objectives allowed Killer Snails (KS) to create a formative assessment dashboard and integrate it with an immersive VR experience, Biodive, to produce an innovative dashboard that measures real-time learning and progress in a virtual environment.  We achieved each of these objectives and as a result, KS received accolades from educational and gaming communities nationwide such as New York City Public Schools, Somers Independent School District, Origins Game Fair and Board Game Geek, validating our business plan and inaugural products. 


The KS team is made up of an active marine biochemist, educational psychologist, Columbia-trained MBA, game developer, game designer and two part time middle school science teachers. We hold a unique market niche by combining our expertise in scientific investigation and educational assessment which allows us to create learning experiences that educate and inspire a new generation of science changemakers. The team brings a collective 50 years of teaching experience to our product development. 

 

To develop BioDive, our virtual reality and digital experience for middle schools students, we piloted first with 10 schools in New York and New Jersey. Following several play-break-fix game play sessions, we completed three complementary components: i) the individual student?s digital science journal ii) six virtual reality scenes and iii) the educator assessment dashboard that updates in realtime with all interactions in virtual reality as well as the individual student responses from their journals. 

After developing a solid beta version of these aspects, Team KS completed a 27 state national pilot to ensure ease of use for remote teachers and students. These activities and the responses from our customer segment successfully demonstrate the feasibility of our innovation and its ability to address the value proposition of teachers by finding ways to align with new Next Generation Science Standards and International Baccalaureate standards and to capture the attention of budding STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) learners.

 

Intellectual Merit  

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project brought  our innovative, educational virtual reality and digital game BioDive to commercialization which we have successfully done with our first paying customers. The intellectual merit of integrating mobile virtual reality into the classroom has been accomplished to rave reviews from our players. In addition, the innovative nature of our work has led to us being thought leaders on using emerging technology in classrooms. We have presented our findings in various venues and conferences including TED, Games For Change, Ed Games Expo, and the 2020 SXSWedu. 

 

Broader/Commercial Impact

The broader impacts of the KS Biodive product is the creation of resources that will improve STEM education nationally and internationally. Our aim is to develop transformative digital and virtual games that inspire players to engage in scientific discovery and become critical thinkers about biodiversity and biomedical applications. During Phase II, Killer Snails playtested our learning games at more than 50 schools and a variety of local and national events including World Maker Faire, Playcrafting Annual Demo Day, Demo Day at the New York Media Center, Rockefeller Science Saturdays, The Feminist Press STEMinism conference, and the New York Annual World Science Festival. In total, we playtested BioDive with over 1200 middle school students who provided invaluable feedback on the digital science journal and the VR experiences. These events in which we shared KS products with a large lay audience were prime opportunities to introduce the KS brand, build brand recognition and help us identify future KS products to meet our customer base and market needs.
